smtools.application.util

Class Messages

  • java.lang.Object
    • smtools.application.util.Messages

  • public final class Messages
extends java.lang.Object
    The Messages class provides a mechanism for implementing a multi-lingual message-database.

    The idea behind this class is that, whenever a String locale is needed, it is replaced by a lookup in the message-database that gives a translation to the currently selected language. The message-database is based on keys and values: the keys provide the lookup-mechanism, whereas the values represent the translations.

    When an application is starting, the database containing the selected messages should be loaded using the static load(String) or load(InputStream) methods. Lookups are performed as follows:

      String translation = Messages.lookup(key,parameters);

    The optional parameters are specified in the keys using (^i) with i the number of the parameter. In order to get the caret itself, it should be escaped by writing it twice (^^).

    Some examples

    • Consider the following message-database file:

        • myFirstKey=my first value
        mySecondKey=my ^1 value

      The following lookups demonstrate its usage:

      • Messages.lookup("myFirstKey") will result in " my first value".

      • Messages.lookup("mySecondKey","second") will result in "my second value".

    • A GUI is typically constructed with statements like the following one:

      •  JLabel label = new JLabel(Messages.lookup("labelKey","parameter 1",...,"parameter N"));

    Note that this class cannot be subclassed!

    Version:
    06/04/2011
    Author:
    Sven Maerivoet

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public static void clear()
        Clears the message-database.

      • load

        public static void load(java.io.InputStream messageInputStream)
                 throws FileReadException
        Loads a message-database from an InputStream.

        The stream should have the following structure: each line should contain at most one (key,value) pair. They are specified as:

          key=value

        Note that although comments are not supported, blank lines are allowed.

        Furthermore, when loading a message-database, all existing keys will be overwritten with the new values.

        Parameters:
        messageInputStream - the InputStream containing the message-database
        Throws:
        FileReadException - if an I/O error occurs during reading from the specified InputStream
        See Also:
        load(String messageFile)

      • load

        public static void load(java.lang.String messageFilename)
                 throws FileDoesNotExistException
        Loads a message-database from a specified file.

        The file should have the following structure: each line should contain at most one (key,value) pair. They are specified as:

          key=value

        Note that although comments are not supported, blank lines are allowed.

        Furthermore, when loading a message-database, all existing keys will be overwritten with the new values.

        Parameters:
        messageFilename - the name of the file containing the message-database
        Throws:
        FileDoesNotExistException - if the file containing the message-database could not be opened

      • lookup

        public static java.lang.String lookup(java.lang.String messageKey,
                      java.lang.String... parameters)
        Looks up a key in the message-database and retrieves its translation.

        Note that when the key is not found, an empty string ("") is returned (not null). Also note that any redundant specified parameters are ignored.

        Parameters:
        messageKey - the key to search for in the message-database
        parameters - the optional parameters to substitute in the translated value
        Returns:
        the value corresponding to the messageKey

      • translateMnemonic

        public static int translateMnemonic(java.lang.String mnemonic)
        Returns the KeyEvent code associated with the specified mnemonic.

        A mnemonic consists of a single character; this method does however relaxes this assumption, as it allows for a complete String to be specified (only the first character is considered). So its convenient for the caller to pass a key as parameter to this method.

        Parameters:
        mnemonic - the mnemonic to retrieve the KeyEvent code from
        Returns:
        the KeyEvent code associated with the specified mnemonic
